subject: Gardening
title: Mycorrhizal Matchmaking
description: A quick win: understand Mycorrhizal Matchmaking.

hook.text: When you plant leeks next to strawberries, underground fungi connect their roots and share resources.

buildup.text: Most garden plants form mycorrhizal partnerships with fungi. The fungi extend root reach by up to 700 times.

discovery.text: Companion plants that share the same mycorrhizal network can exchange phosphorus, nitrogen, and even defense signals.

twist.text: Brassicas don't form mycorrhizal connections. Planting them near mycorrhizal crops can disrupt the network.

climax.text: Good companion planting considers the underground network. Some pairings strengthen the fungal web; others break it.

punchline.text: The best companions share the same fungal internet.

quiz.question: Why should brassicas be placed carefully in companion planting schemes?
options: They produce too much shade for neighboring plants
They don't form mycorrhizal connections and can disrupt nearby networks
They deplete soil nitrogen faster than any other crop family
